name: Memory Management: Protect & Forget
description: Covers PROTECT, UNPROTECT, FORGET (threshold-based and pattern-based), and verifies forgotten concepts are no longer answerable while protected ones remain.

theory.natural_language: We have several concepts: KeepMe is important, DropMe is temporary, CoreConcept is essential, TempData is throwaway, Archive is old data, Critical is vital, Scratch1 and Scratch2 are scratch items. We test various protect/forget scenarios.

queries.natural_language: After protecting KeepMe and forgetting low-usage concepts, is KeepMe still known as important?

expected_answer.natural_language: Yes. KeepMe was protected before forgetting, so it should still be known as important.
expected_answer.explanation: PROTECT prevents deletion; FORGET threshold=2 removes only unprotected low-usage concepts.

queries.natural_language: After the same forgetting pass, is DropMe still known as temporary?

expected_answer.natural_language: No information remains about DropMe; it was removed by forgetting.
expected_answer.explanation: DropMe was not protected and had low usage, so FORGET removed its facts.

queries.natural_language: Can we protect CoreConcept and verify it survives a higher threshold forget?

expected_answer.natural_language: Yes. Protected concepts survive any threshold-based forgetting.
expected_answer.explanation: PROTECT marks concept as immune to FORGET operations.

queries.natural_language: After unprotecting and forgetting, is a previously protected concept gone?

expected_answer.natural_language: No. After unprotecting, TempData is subject to forgetting.
expected_answer.explanation: UNPROTECT removes protection; subsequent FORGET removes the concept.

queries.natural_language: Does Archive survive when we forget with a very high threshold?

expected_answer.natural_language: Yes. Protected Archive survives even aggressive forgetting thresholds.

queries.natural_language: Is Critical still known after protecting it multiple times?

expected_answer.natural_language: Yes. Multiple PROTECT calls are idempotent; concept remains protected.
expected_answer.explanation: PROTECT is idempotent; concept stays protected.

queries.natural_language: After forgetting, is Scratch1 still known?
queries.expected_dsl:
@forget4 FORGET threshold=2
@q7 ASK Scratch1 IS_A scratch_item

expected_answer.natural_language: No. Unprotected low-usage concepts are forgotten.
expected_answer.explanation: Scratch1 had no protection and low usage.

queries.natural_language: Verify Scratch2 is also gone after the same forget pass.

expected_answer.natural_language: No. Scratch2 was also unprotected and had low usage.
expected_answer.explanation: Both scratch items are removed by the same FORGET operation.
